MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Killarney Shoe Factory Strike.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy John O'Leary has been given permission to raise on the Adjournment the subject matter of a Private Notice Question today. Deputy O'Leary will have to read his Private Notice Question if he has it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I gave notice of my intention to ask a Private Notice Question, namely, to ask the Minister for Labour if he will personally intervene as a matter of extreme urgency to settle the strike at Tuf Shoes factory in Killarney, County Kerry, in view of the proposals to wind down operations in the factory as from tomorrow, Wednesday, 26 June 1985 and the serious danger of the loss of 100 jobs; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

I thank the Ceann Comhairle for giving me permission to raise this matter on the Adjournment of the Dáil tonight. First of all, this strike has been on since 7 June and I understand that there has been no direct intervention by the Minister so far. I understand also that a meeting has been arranged between the management and the union for Thursday but my latest information tonight is that the management will just inform the union again that they intend to stick to their decision.

The history of this industry is most interesting. This industry was started by people making handmade shoes in 1881. In 1936 the present premises were built and occupied by a firm known as Hilliard and Palmer who were most successful in the manufacture of footwear. In 1963-64 this company was taken over by G.B. Britten and operated under G.B. Britten for a few years. Then a company known as Tuf Shoes, Killarney, was formed and the company has been trading since then as Tuf Shoes, Killarney. I understand that this industry reached its peak in the late sixties and the seventies.

MainHeading.P: Over the past three or four years persons who left or retired were not replaced due to what is termed natural wastage. It is well known that employees in the clothing and footwear industries are not paid as well as employees in other manufacturing industries and this must be taken very much into account when considering the situation which now prevails in the Tuf Shoes factory in Killarney. We must also bear in mind the fact that all the employees of the company have given loyal and faithful service to the company. Very few firms and manufacturing companies in this country have had such a loyal and faithful staff as have Tuf Shoes, Killarney, and their predecessors in the running of this enterprise. Tuf Shoes, Killarney, supplied the Army and the prison service with boots, shoes and footwear for a long number of years. They also supplied the Department of Posts and Telegraphs and the ESB for many years.

The company proposed some time ago to make 25 to 30 employees redundant on the grounds that it is the intention of the company to rationalise operations in the plant. The kernel of the problem is the rate of redundancy to be paid to those being made redundant. I understand that the company decided to pay more or less according to the Act which would entail half a week's pay for every year of service plus a week's pay. I understand also that this was discussed by the Labour Court and also by the Conciliation and Arbitration Board but the employees are not happy about the method by which the assessment and the award were made by the Labour Court and by the Conciliation and Arbitration Board.

Management say that the whole purpose of the rationalisation programme is to hold on to the 95 jobs. Very few are disputing this. The kernel of the problem is the rate of redundancy which the company propose to pay to their employees. Common sense must prevail and there is an obligation on the Minister to intervene personally in this case. One of the major functions of the Minister for Labour and his Department is to monitor disputes, particularly disputes leading to a strike and the possibility of ultimate closure of an industrial enterprise. In this case we are talking about an industry which is perhaps the oldest in Killarney, if not in all County Kerry.

Killarney has suffered much from unemployment in recent years and the rate of emigration, particularly among young people, has been alarmingly high during the past year. Employees are anxious to know whether the Labour Court when assessing the situation took into account the company's profits in recent years. I appeal to the Minister to intervene immediately, to call both sides together to settle the dispute and save the 95 jobs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I can readily understand Deputy O'Leary's concern in raising this matter since it affects his constituency. He and the other Deputies in the constituency of South Kerry are legitimately concerned. I wish to restate the responsibilities of the Minister for Labour in the area of industrial relations. The role of the Minister for Labour is to ensure that there is an adequate and effective system of industrial relations machinery available to both sides within the operation of our open, democratic system to enable them to resolve whatever differences arise in a manner which results in the minimum disruption in terms of industrial stoppages.

As a corollary to that, I do not believe it is the responsibility of the Minister to intervene directly in individual disputes unless there are overriding reasons of a nationwide dimension that would warrant it. My immediate predecessor, Deputy Liam Kavanagh, was very strongly of this view and established a position which has strengthened the entire industrial relations machinery. If participants on either side felt that they could have a fast track to the Minister for Labour of the day they would disregard all the intermediate stages in the industrial relations field and would not avail of the professional machinery that exists to enable them to resolve their disputes.

MainHeading.P: I am not a professional industrial relations specialist, nor have been most of my predecessors. There are, however, in the Labour Court, the trade union movement and the employers' organisations people whose skill it is to assist in the resolution of such disputes and who have given their life to such work. It is our responsibility as a Legislature and my responsibility as Minister for Labour to ensure that the skilled people in the area are given the support of our system of enable them to bring about a resolution of a conflict wherever it arises in the industrial relations scheme. I believe this is the correct position for the Minister and the Department of Labour.

This dispute essentially concerns the 24th pay round and the terms of a redundancy programme proposed by the management. Following conciliation conferences the Labour Court investigated both issues. As the House knows, the Labour Court is a body representing the social partners and independent members and has won the trust and respect of both sides of industry over many years. Indeed, the Labour Court is literally as old as myself, established in the year of my birth. It has a whole body of case law and precedent. In this case the recommendation of the Labour Court was firstly, that the company's offer of a 3 per cent wage increase for six months, followed by a review after implementation of a rationalisation programme, should be accepted by the workforce; secondly, workers made redundant under the rationalisation programme should receive their statutory entitlements only. This is the nub of the issue.

The workers represented by the Irish Transport and General Workers Union rejected both the Labour Court recommendations and strike action started on 6 June last. It is understood that the company improved on the terms recommended by the Labour Court but that this improvement was not acceptable to the union. The company have indicated that no further improvement is possible and that they propose to wind down operations if there is not a return to work by Wednesday, 26 June.

My Department were aware of this problem. We have a monitoring group which was established by Deputy O'Leary's namesake when Minister for Labour. The monitoring group have been in contact with the Labour Court, who have arranged for an industrial relations officer to convene another conciliation conference on Thursday in Mallow. Both sides have indicated that they will attend the conference. I would support that meeting and publicly request the company to defer any action which they were proposing for tomorrow until such time as the outcome of the meeting with the IRO is known. I do not see that I can do anything more which would be helpful to the interests of the workers in the Tuf factory in Killarney. It is for their union representatives to negotiate an improved settlement if that is possible and for the company to respond as best they can.

The position is, quite clearly, that the industrial relations which exist have been brought into play and made available to both sides. As Deputy O'Leary said, there is a history related to this factory and we know that the shoe industry has gone through a certain amount of restructuring and market change. I urge both sides to approach the conciliation conference in Mallow on Thursday in a spirit of constructive compromise, with a view to finding a satisfactory solution to this problem. that is all that I can do and I ask everybody to refrain from making any further comment on the dispute at this stage so that the outcome of the conciliation conference will not be prejudiced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Would the Minister ask his Department to keep the situation under continuous examination?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Deputy may take it that following his raising of the matter we will pay particular attention to it and keep it under review.
The Dáil adjourned at 11.03 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 26 June 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if it is likely that in the near future we will have in this country smoke-free zones; if arrangements for these are in an advanced stage in his Department; and if certain areas are to be selected in respect of such zones.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: In conjunction with the preparation of new air pollution legislation, various options aimed at improving air quality are being examined. These include the need for designating specific areas as smokeless zones and the implications and effectiveness of such measures. I hope to be in a position to introduce the new legislation later this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Atmospheric and Marine Pollution.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is satisfied with existing levels of atmospheric and marine pollution in the Dublin area; if he will indicate the measures being taken to reduce levels of pollution; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: A statement of the kind requested by the Deputy would have to cover a wide range of issues and would, of necessity, have to be a very lengthy one if it were to deal comprehensively with the existing situation and with policy and proposals for future action in relation to atmospheric and marine pollution in the Dublin area. Such a statement could not appropriately be made at Question Time. I have, however, dealt with various aspects of the subject in replies to Dáil questions and in other statements in recent months. I have now placed in the Library copies of a recent lengthy address on the subject of pollution of sea and air which I delivered at a public meeting in Dublin on 22 April last. I trust that this will provide the information requested by the Deputy.

On 18 June, I made regulations entitled Control of Atmospheric Pollution (Licensing) Regulations, 1985, which deal with air pollution caused by the extraction or recovery of certain metals from scrap metal, waste material and waste cable and which establish a licensing system, to be operated by sanitary authorities, for any trade, works or process in which burning or the application of heat is used to extract or recover such metals. I have already informed the House that comprehensive new air pollution legislation, which will take account of national and international requirements, is at an advanced stage of preparation and I hope to be in a position to introduce the Bill in the autumn.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will comment on the situation where local bodies and health boards are required to adhere to the terms of the proposed building regulations whereas private concerns or individuals are not required to adhere to them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: In May 1984 I asked all those concerned to regard the proposed building regulations as having the force of law and to apply the standards in the regulations when designing and constructing buildings. This request applies equally to local authorities, health boards and private concerns and individuals but naturally I would expect public bodies to give a lead in meeting the requirements set out in the proposed regulations which, after all, represent good building practice.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The total cost of advertising the six liaison officer positions on the 1986 Census of Population was £2,862.03, including £535.18 VAT.

MainHeading.P: The Census of Population is probably the only Government activity which involves every household in the State in respect of one particular date and there is considerable interaction between the general public and the field force of about 3,400 enumerators. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Bord na Móna Superannuation Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy if he is aware that the principal amendments to the Bord na Móna (Superannuation) Scheme, 1963, have not yet been published; and if he will state the full terms of the latest provisions, as approved by his Department affecting preserved benefits following (a) resignation and (b) redundancy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy if he is aware that the principal amendments to the Bord na Móna (Superannuation) Scheme, 1963, have not yet been published as regulations; and if he will state the full, current terms of the 1978 amendment scheme as subsequently amended in 1980.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 18 and 19 together. Bord na Móna operate three superannuation schemes; one for their general employees, one for their regular employees and one for whole-time members of the board. It is assumed that the Deputy's questions relate to the Turf Development Act, 1953 (Regular Works Employees) Superannuation Scheme, 1963 and its amending schemes.

The 1963 scheme, and seven subsequent amending schemes, have received the approval of the Minister and the concurrence of the Minister for the Public Service, or the Minister for Finance as provided in earlier legislation. Before the schemes were made, they were published in accordance with the provisions of section 6 of the Turf Development Act, 1953. When the schemes were made, they were laid before each House of the Oireachtas. It has not been the practice to have the schemes published as regulations. The 1980 and 1982 amending schemes contain the most recent references to resignation and redundancy. Copies of the relevant documents are available in Bord na Móna for inspection by members of the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 21 and 22 together.

I am informed that the Industrial Development Authority are actively promoting their 55 acre site at Collinstown, Leixlip, County Kildare, for a suitable major industrial project. As the Deputy is aware, outline planning permission has been acquired for the site. Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Industrial Development Authority, the body responsible for the promotion of industrial development, that they have no plans to provide an enterprise centre in Leixlip, County Kildare. The authority have, however, acquired a 55 acre site in Leixlip and this is being actively promoted for a suitable major industrial project.

In Celbridge, a few miles from Leixlip, the local community council have provided an enterprise centre and this is capable of meeting the demand for space for small industry in the area at present. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Participation in EXPO 86.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism whether the Government have given consideration to participating in the international exhibition EXPO 1986 in Canada; and, if not, whether he is aware that, with the exception of Portugal, it is understood that Ireland will be the only other non-participating country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: The question of participating in EXPO 86 has been considered on a number of occasions. The exposition is basically of a non-commercial nature dealing with transport and communications and estimated to be of very little trade benefit to Ireland. Because of the theme of the exposition, the Minister for Communications took the lead role in deciding on attendance. On being consulted and having discussed the matter with the promotion agencies under my control, Córas Tráchtála, Bórd Fáilte and the IDA, I advised the Minister for Communications that because of the specialist nature of the exposition it was felt that any benefit to be gained from participating would not justify the expenditure necessary to mount a national stand.

I understand that the Minister for Communications consulted the relevant semi-State bodies under his aegis which are involved in the area of transport and communications and was satisfied that because of financial and other constraints none of the bodies would be in a position to take part in the exposition. On the basis of the various views expressed, the Minister for Communications decided that Ireland would not participate in EXPO 86. This decision was conveyed to the Canadian authorities through the Department of Foreign Affairs in May 1984.

MainHeading.P: Following further representations from the Canadian authorities the matter was reconsidered but again it was decided not to participate.

Of the EC member states, United Kingdom, Germany, Italy, France and Belgium will all amount national exhibits. In common with the remaining member states Ireland will not be mounting a national stand but will be represented on the Community exhibit.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Management Plan for Dublin Bay.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the stage the Water Quality Management Plan for Dublin Bay requested by him from the three local authorities in the Dublin region has reached; the reason no announcement was made to make interested groups aware of such an initiative; and if the public, particularly the users, will be informed of the terms of reference for the preparation of such a management plan or if this will appear after the plan has been completed as happened with the Eastern Regional Development Organisation's recently published controversial plan for the Greater Dublin area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware that the Eastern Regional Development Organisation does not represent environmental or user interests; and if there are representatives of the environmental interest and the user groups on the steering committee for the Management Plan for Dublin Bay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 76 and 78 together. In September 1984, the Minister of State at my Department requested the three Dublin local authorities to co-operate in the preparation of a water quality management plan for Dublin Bay, and statements in regard to the matter were subsequently made by me and by the Minister of State in Dáil Éireann and elsewhere. The members of all three local authorities have since approved of proposals that An Foras Forbartha be requested to undertake the studies required for the preparation of such a plan for the bay and the tidal section of the River Liffey, and that the Eastern Regional Development Organisation would commission An Foras to carry out the work and provide the necessary co-ordination of the project.

A steering committee is to define the parameters of the study, draft terms of reference and generally oversee the work as it proceeds. The committee is composed of representatives of the three local authorities and the Department of the Environment, while independent professionals in the environmental field have also been invited to join the committee. There will be scope for other organisations to make an input in the preparation of the plan; it will be a matter for the steering committee to decide when submissions should be invited. When a draft is available, it will be put on public display for at least three months so that representations can be made and considered by the local authorities before formally adopting the plan.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EC Bathing Water Directive.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the number of beaches in Ireland designated as bathing beaches for the purposes of compliance with the Bathing Water Directive 76/160/EC; if he sends bathing quality data for designated beaches to the EC; and, if so, if he will outline the EC observations on this data.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The directive to which the Deputy refers applies to waters where bathing is specifically authorised or traditionally practised by a large number of bathers. Because of the terms of the directive, it is deemed not to apply to any bathing waters in Ireland but, in order to conform with the spirit of the directive, six beaches have been selected for monitoring: Portmarnock, Dollymount, Courtown, Tramore, Fountainstown and Salthill. Monitoring is carried out at these beaches fortnightly during the bathing season and a report is submitted to the EC Commission each year. The Commission's comments on the monitoring procedure in Ireland (made in first report which dealt with the type of data required) were taken into account in the compilation and presentation of bathing water results in subsequent years. I am not aware of any further comment by the Commission on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the total costs, in respect of the last five years, incurred by his Department for hospital charges and consultant's fees arising from the treatment of road traffic accident victims; and the amounts of money, if any, recovered by his Department from insurance awards or from the insurance companies involved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: It has not been the practice to determine actual costs of maintenance and treatment for individual patients, or for patient categories. Consequently it is not possible to state, with any degree of precision, the total cost to the Exchequer involved in the provision of services for road traffic accident cases.

Charges in respect of the treatment of such cases were levied by the hospitals concerned. Charges initially raised related to the hospitals concerned. Charges initially raised related to the hospital's overall average daily costs covering both maintenance and treatment. These charges were subject to reduction or waiver in the light of the amount, if any, of damages or compensation received by the persons liable for the charges. In the years 1980 to 1984, inclusive, receipts in respect of services provided for road accidents cases amounted to approximately £7 million.

MainHeading.P: There is generally a considerable time lag between the initial raising of charges and the receipts of payments. Consequently substantial amounts were outstanding at the end of the period mentioned in respect of services provided during the period. On 16 December 1983 the Supreme Court held the Regulation, under which the charges were raised, to be ultra vires the power of the Minister and void. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Outbreak of Botulism.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health in view of the fact that seabird deaths in Dublin Bay last summer were caused by botulism (type C), if he has any contingency plan in case of a major outbreak of botulism this year, with particular reference to (1) the safe disposal of affected birds; (2) the checks for types of botulism as some are highly dangerous to humans; and (3) where birds pick up the poison.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: Type C botulism occurs in birds and other animals but rarely affects humans. Soil and water are reservoirs of infection and the toxin is produced under anaerobic conditions. I have been informed by Dublin Corporation, which is the responsible authority, that in the event of an outbreak of botulism among seabirds, the dead birds will be cleared away and deep buried in line with recommended procedures, as was done during last summer's outbreak.

MainHeading.P: Type A, B and E botulism present the greatest risk to humans. I would point out that there has been no case of botulism in humans in this country since records have been kept. However as a precautionary measure, antitoxins to the common types are kept at Cherry Orchard Hospital. In addition the Department of Medical Microbiology at University College Galway has been designated the official centre for the analysis of food for the presence of botulism. In the event of botulism toxin being suspected in any case, samples are sent there for analysis. My Department also participate in the EC system for the rapid exchange of information on dangers arising from the use of consumer products which provides early warning of health risks from contaminated food.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason a person (details supplied) in Dublin 5 is only in receipt of £10 pension; and the reason his wife is only in receipt of £2.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned reached age 65 on 7 April 1984. He then resided in Britain and details of his claim for retirement pension were received from the British Authorities on 22 May 1985.

One of the qualifying conditions for receipt of a retirement pension under the Social Welfare Acts requires a person to have a yearly average of at least 24 reckonable contributions over the period from the beginning of the 1953 contribution year or from his year of entry into insurance, whichever is the later, to the end of the last complete contribution year before reaching pension age. The person concerned does not satisfy this condition as the Department's records show that he had a total of 199 reckonable contributions in the relevant period which, in his case, is from 5 January 1953 to 5 April 1984. This is equal to a yearly average of only six and, therefore, he does not qualify for a retirement pension under the Social Welfare Acts. Neither did he qualify for old age contributory pension at age 66; a yearly average of at least 20 is required for this latter pension.

MainHeading.P: He was insurably employed in Britain from 1956 to 1984. Under EC Regulations on social security a person who has been employed in another member state can qualify for a pro rata retirement pension on his combined Irish and British records, the amount payable being based on the number of his Irish contributions in proportion to the combined total. His total of 199 Irish and 1,426 British contributions entitles him to a pro rata pension of £10.30 per week, at present rates. This includes an allowance of £4.40 in respect of his wife. He is also in receipt of a British retirement pension.

The Department have no record of a pension payment of £2 to his wife. If this is a payment being made by the British Department of Health and Social Security any inquiry regarding it should be addressed to that Department in Newcastle-upon-Tyne.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if, in view of her special circumstances, he will grant a deserted wife's allowance to a person (details supplied) in Dublin 22 who has made every effort through the courts to trace her husband.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Two of the conditions for the receipt of a deserted wife's payment are that a husband must have left his wife of his own volition and that she must make and continue to make reasonable efforts to trace her husband and to prevail on him to contribute to the support and maintenance of herself and her children. The deciding officer held that these conditions were not satisfied in this case and disallowed the claim of the person concerned. She appealed against the decision and after an oral hearing of the case on 12 November 1979 an appeals officer disallowed the appeal.

Since then the claimant has made a number of further applications for payment which have all been refused. The most recent was on 14 May 1985 when she forwarded a copy of a maintenance order she had obtained against her husband. However, an attempt to serve an attachment of earnings order on the husband was unsuccessful as he had apparently left his job. The appeals officer accepted at that stage that she had made the necessary efforts to obtain maintenance. He also held, however, that the other ground on which the claim was refused, viz. that her husband had not left her of his own volition was still in effect. She is not therefore entitled to a deserted wife's payment and she has been notified to this effect.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Payment of unemployment benefit is normally made from the 4th day of unemployment in a period of interruption of employment. However, any two periods of interruption of employment not separated by more than 13 weeks are treated as one period of interruption of employment.

MainHeading.P: The person concerned claimed unemployment benefit to 27 February 1985 after which date he ceased to sign as unemployed as he commenced participation on an AnCO course. He again registered as unemployed from 3 June 1985 and his claim was allowed at the weekly rate of £80.15. As these two dates are separated by a period in excess of 13 weeks, under the legislation he would not be entitled to unemployment benefit for the first three days of the second period of interruption of employment. However, the exact period during which the course in question took place has not been verified and the matter will be clarified with the claimant on his next attendance at the exchange.

The general position governing entitlement to unemployment benefit of claimants who resume signing the unemployment register after participation at an AnCO course is at present under examination in the Department. Any changes in the present arrangements in this regard would involve amending legislation and would be for consideration in the context of the annual Social Welfare Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Allowances for dependent children under the retirement pensions scheme are paid up to age 18 which is the general age limit for child dependant allowances under the social welfare code. Persons aged over 18 are entitled to claim unemployment assistance in their own right if they satisfy the conditions of being unemployed, available and genuinely seeking work. Full time attendance at a course of education, however, is not consistent with being available for work. It would be open to the person concerned to apply for a qualification certificate at her local employment exchange which will enable her to apply for unemployment assistance when she becomes available for work.
The Commission on Social Welfare is examining the issue of child dependency as part of a comprehensive review of the welfare system.

My Department have recently published a new leaflet entitled “Social Welfare and School-Leavers.” Copies of this have been sent to the Deputy and I am arranging for copies to be sent also to the person in question for information.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: One of the qualifying conditions for the receipt of a contributory old age pension requires the claimant to have a yearly average of at least 20 reckonable contributions from 6 July 1953 or from her year of entry into insurance, whichever is the later, to the end of the last complete contribution year before she reaches pension age.

The Department's records show that the person concerned has a total of 384 reckonable contributions in the relevant period which in her case, is from 6 July 1953 to 5 April 1980. This is equal to a yearly average of only 14 and, therefore, she does not qualify for a contributory old age pension under the Social Welfare Acts.

Under EC regulations the contribution records of a person who was employed in two or more EC member states may be combined to enable her to qualify for a pro-rata pension. However, she had a total of only 54 British contributions since 1953 and her combined Irish and British total in the period from 6 July 1953 to 5 April 1980 is equal to a yearly average of only 16. She does not, therefore qualify for a pro-rata pension under EC regulations.

Speaker.P: One of the conditions for the receipt of a deserted wife's payment is that a husband must have left his wife of his own voliation.

The deciding officer held that this condition was not satisfied in the case of the person concerned and disallowed her claim. She was notified to this effect and of her right to appeal if she was dissatisfied with the decision.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: One of the conditions for the receipt of deserted wife's allowance/ benefit is that a claimant must make and continue to make reasonable efforts within the means available to her to trace her husband's whereabouts and prevail on him to contribute to her support and that of her children. In addition, to qualify for a benefit payment there must be at least 156 Irish paid insurance contributions (either on her own or her husband's insurance record) between the date of entry into insurance and the date of desertion. The deciding officer held that in this case the person concerned who was claiming deserted wife's benefit did not satisfy these conditions.

MainHeading.P: She appealed against the decision and the deciding officer subsequently accepted that the first condition was satisfied but the insurance contributions disqualification still stood. She was notified to this effect on 3 December 1984 and informed of the number of insurance contributions paid by her and her husband up to the date of his leaving. She was also requested to inform the Department if, in the circumstances, She wished to pursue her appeal. There is no trace of the receipt of a reply from her. As far as the Department is aware, the claimant is working and her income from the employment would render her ineligible for receipt of deserted wife's allowance, which is a means tested payment. If her circumstances have changed, however, or if they change in the future she could claim the allowance.

Speaker.P: Payments from the Depopulation Fund (formerly the Hardship Fund) are confined to cases where herds have to be depopulated because of very severe infection with TB or brucellosis. Depopulation of the herd of the person named is not contemplated and, therefore, the question of a payment from the fund does not arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will pay grant aid under the farm modernisation scheme to a person (details supplied) in County Louth which was disallowed even though the development was part of a farm development plan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: No application for grant aid under the scheme was made to the farm development service in this case. As the work was carried out without the prior written approval of the FDS, it is not eligible for aid under the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Brennan Mr. P. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason a suckler calf subsidy has not been paid to a person (details supplied) in County Wicklow.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Calf premium and calved heifer grants have not been paid to the person named as my Department is not satisfied that the animals on which grants are being claimed are his property.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will approve a grant to a person (details supplied) in County Roscommon for release from a milk quota.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: It is assumed the Deputy is referring to an application to join the milk cessation scheme. This scheme was oversubscribed and selection had to be made by ballot. The person indicated was not successful in the ballot.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transfer of Milk Quota.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when he will sanction a milk quota transfer from Waterford Cooperative to Wexford Cheese for a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The transfer of the milk quota will be sanctioned when the details of the land transfer transaction involved, which is currently being investigated by the Department, have been confirmed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will arrange for the immediate payment of all cattle and sheep headage grants due to a person (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The person named has been paid his 1984 cattle headage grants under the disadvantaged areas schemes and his 1984 suckler cow premium already. He will be paid his calf premium in respect of a calf born between 16 June 1984 and 31 December 1984 when payments commence in July 1985. Headage grants have been paid to him in respect of all sheep which my Department believes were his property.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will arrange for the immediate payment of mountain and hill pasture improvement scheme grants to a person (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: An inspection made on 31 May 1985 showed that the approved work in this case had not been fully carried out and the applicant was informed of what was necessary to enable the grant application to be processed. When he notifies the local farm development service that the work has been completed as required a further inspection will take place.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kildare Policing Arrangements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he has any further plans to improve the policing of the towns of Maynooth, Leixlip and Celbridge in County Kildare.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will consider the acquisition of a site at Main Street, Leixlip, County Kildare, for the provision of a Garda station to serve the area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he has reconsidered the case for the provision of a Garda station at Leixlip, County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: , Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 345 to 347, inclusive together. I am informed by the Garda authorities that there are no proposals at present for increasing Garda strength at Maynooth, Leixlip or Celbridge. Policing arrangements for the towns of Maynooth and Celbridge will, however, benefit from the first phase of the new national Garda communications network which is due to come into operation next month in areas outside the Dublin Metropolitan Area.

I have consulted the Garda authorities again about the question of providing a Garda station at Leixlip and they still consider that the present arrangement whereby the area is served from Lucan station makes the best use of available resources. They have also indicated that as a result of impending organisational change affecting the Lucan Garda sub-district, it is hoped to effect some improvement in the policing of Leixlip and the matter will be kept under review.

There was a substantial reduction in the level of indictable crime in the Lucan Garda sub-district last year and provisional figures for the first quarter of this year indicate a further improvement in the crime situation there. The downward trend in the crime rate is encouraging and I hope that this improvement can be maintained.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Policing of Dublin Area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will make a statement in connection with the policing of an area (details supplied) in Dublin; if he is aware that residents' associations and groups are being advised by a parent Garda station for that area that gardaí are being allocated to VIP protection to the detriment of local policing; if this information is correct; if this is not correct, if he will ensure that those who are giving this as an explanation desist from doing so; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The detailed policing arrangements for individual areas are a matter for the Garda authorities and the allocation of manpower between protection duty and other duties is a matter for the local Garda officers having regard to available resources, local circumstances and other demands on Garda services. I an informed by the Garda authorities that it is not correct to say that gardaí are being deployed on VIP protection duty to the detriment of other police duties in the area concerned and that they have been unable to confirm that such a statement was made by any member of the force.

Garda strength at the two stations serving the area, which takes account of special commitments such as protection duty, has been increased by a total of 35 members since 1 January 1983 and the service provided from these stations is currently being supplemented by assistance from elsewhere in the Dublin Metropolitan Area. The policing arrangements for the area are being kept under review by the Garda authorities and the question of a further increase in strength at the two local stations will be further considered when the next group of Garda recruits becomes available for assignment in August.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason for the delay in the consideration of the application for naturalisation on behalf of a person (details supplied) in Dublin; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The reason for the delay in finalising this application was the difficulty, due to his frequent changes of address and employment, in assessing the applicant in relation to the statutory conditions for the granting of a certificate of naturalisation. I have decided now to grant him a certificate of naturalisation. My Department will contact him in the near future concerning finalisation of the remaining formalities.
Question No. 350 withdrawn.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Extension of Portlaoise Prison Facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the purpose for which the New houses and 60-bedroom unit constructed at Portlaoise prison were provided, and if they were intended as part of the proposed new prison complex.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: , Limerick East): The 60 new houses for married prison service personnel and the staff residence for 60 unmarried personnel constructed on part of the prison farm in Portlaoise were provided to cater for the staff accommodation needs of the existing prison and the proposed new high level security prison. To an extent the accommodation built replaced existing accommodation which, as well as being in bad condition and deemed to be no longer suitable, needed in any event to be demolished for security reasons.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Barna (Galway) School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the application for an additional classroom at Boleybeg national school, Barna, County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department in March 1985 approved the position of a prefabricated classroom at Boleybeg national school, Barna, County Galway. The Commissioners of Public Works are at present in the course of advising the chairman of the school's board of management as to the further necessary steps to be taken.

MainHeading.P: My Department has asked the commissioners to undertake a feasibility study on how best the long term future accommodation needs of the school may be met. On receipt of this report my Department will communicate with the school authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Post Primary Special Education.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Faulkner Mr. Faulkner
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the provision that is being made for post primary education for mildly mentally handicapped children.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: In order to assist post primary schools in catering for the second level educational needs of pupils who have been catered for up to that stage in special classes in primary schools my Department will to the extent of resources available authorise a teaching post in an appropriate post primary school in addition to the normal quota. Such additional resources are at present provided in 16 post primary schools and this provision is being expanded. A number of applications are at present under consideration in connection with the authorisation of further posts for the school year 1985-86. An appropriate curriculum to meet the needs of these pupils is also being prepared.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Primary Schools Capitation Grant.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the serious financial difficulties facing the management boards of primary schools at this time; and, if so, the measures she proposes to take to alleviate their position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I am aware that the boards of management of many national schools have encountered difficulties in meeting running costs and, for this reason, the capitation grant was increased by £4, to £21 per pupil, in respect of the 1983-84 school year and by a further £1, to £22 per pupil, in respect of the 1984-85 school year. The question of the level of capitation grant for 1985-86 will be considered in the context of the Estimates for Public Services, 1986.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Eligibility for Educational Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the eligibility for grant aid in respepct of third level education in the North for students from the South who had attended a second level school in the North will be reviewed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Under the provisions of the Local Authorities (Higher Education Grants) Act, 1968, local authorities are empowered to award grants only to persons who achieve prescribed successes in the leaving certificate examination of my Department. Accordingly it is open to local authorities to consider the award of grants to student who were educated in Northern Ireland and who sat for the leaving certificate examination provided the parents or guardians were ordinarily resident in the administrative area of the relevant local rating authority. The question of accepting successes in examinations other than the leaving certificate examination is, however, being considered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if there are any controls or regulations regarding work experience in view of the fact that a person (details supplied) in Dublin 5 who was qualified as a secretarial assistant obtained two weeks work experience recently which only involved making tea.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Schools participating in the vocational preparation and training programme are required to ensure that forms of experience of work placements during the course of the programme are properly monitored and integrated into the overall programme. In addition the schools are required to liaise with the trainee and/or work supervisor during the work experience placement to ensure that the placement is operating satisfactorily. In the case of the person mentioned by the Deputy the school authorities have informed me that all the requirements of the scheme were fulfilled and that the person in question did not make any complaint in regard to the nature and extent of the placement. I have, however, brought the Deputy's representations to the attention of the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. T. Cosgrave Mr. L. T. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the urgent need for repairs to a school (details supplied) in County Dublin; and if she will ensure that her Department will have these repairs carried out without delay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department has under consideration a report dated 20 June 1985 received from the Commissioners of Public Works in connection with the improvements required at the school referred to by the Deputy. My Department will communicate with the school authorities as soon as possible as to the extent of the assistance which it can offer towards the cost of undertaking the required works.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when she proposes to appoint a remedial teacher for a school (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: A remedial teaching post for the school in question was sanctioned by my Department in November 1982. The school has had the services of a remedial teacher since February 1983. An application for a second remedial post for the school was made in May 1984. The application has not, to date, been placed sufficiently high in order of priority of educational need to warrant the allocation of a second post. The application will, however, be further considered in the light of the availability of further remedial posts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will give an indication of the likely date by which provision of an extension to St. Farnan's post primary school, Prosperous, County Kildare, will take place.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will, as a matter of urgency, grant her approval for the extension to St. Farnan's post primary school, Prosperous, County Kildare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 359 and 360 together.

Approval was given on 3 May last to County Kildare Vocational Education Committee to proceed with the preparation of the bills of quantities for the extension to Prosperous vocational school. The submission of this documentation is now awaited in my Department. Pending the completion of the planning procedures, I am not in a position to say when construction of the extension will be started.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make a statement on the progress made to date on the provision of a new second level school in Rathkeale, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The new post primary school which has been sanctioned for Rathkeale will replace the existing convent and vocational schools. The existing vocational school building will be retained as part of the new school and it is proposed to build the balance of the accommodation on an adjacent site. Negotiations with regard to the purchase of the new site are in progress. Consultants have been appointed for the project and architectural planning will proceed when the question of the site has been resolved.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Education of Disabled Children.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will comment on an article (details supplied) regarding the education of disabled children; and if she will arrange for the development of such a facility in Irish schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The responsible officials in my Department keep in constant touch with developments in the field of special education both at home and abroad with a view to having the best possible facilities available in Irish schools. A proposal for the education of some mentally handicapped children in the Dublin area has been made by the person who supplied the Deputy with the article in question and this proposal is under consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the type of structure of educational facilities which will be provided in Drangan national school, County Tipperary, following the reconstruction and amalgamation; if her Department will allow a senior and junior school within the complex which would ensure the Sisters of Mercy's continued participation as teachers there; and when this decision will be made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Two co-educational national schools will be accommodated on the premises which has recently been extended: a junior school which will be conducted by the Sisters of Mercy and a senior schools with a staff of lay teachers.
The boards of management of the present schools have been informed of the reorganisation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Grant Eligibility.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. A. Doyle Mrs. A. Doyle
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether her recent announcement relating to the income eligibility conditions for third level grants could be made retrospective to allow these conditions to apply to existing students whose parents may be marginally over the income limit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The income limits that apply to a candidate for a higher education grant are those of the scheme of the year he/she qualified for a grant on grounds of attainments by virtue of successes in the leaving certificate examination. Accordingly, the revised eligibility limits in the scheme for 1985 are not retrospective. They apply only to candidates who qualify academically in the leaving certificate this year (1985).

This has been the position since the inception of the scheme in 1968 and is regarded as being the most fair and equitable basis of administration of the scheme taking into account all the relevant considerations and circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Crotty Mr. Crotty
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position with regard to the proposed extension to Ballyragget national school, County Kilkenny; and when work will commence.

Speaker.P: My Department has under consideration a report, from the Commissioners of Public Works, on the tenders received for the proposed extension to Ballyragget Convent national school, County Kilkenny. A decision on the question of placing a contract for the project will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Caretakers of Secondary Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will give consideration to the caretakers of secondary schools as is being given to the caretakers of primary schools with regard to the receipt of pensions and salaries from her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The employment of caretakers in secondary schools and their conditions of employment (pay, pension, etc.) are matters for the authorities of those schools. My Department pays capitation grants to secondary schools but there is no fund specifically for the payment of caretakers employed in secondary schools. The possible application of the social employment scheme to this area is being examined at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason for the delay in the acceptance of a tender for the extension to Clontibret national school, County Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding the proposed extention to Corracrin national school, County Monaghan; and when it will be advertised for tender.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position with regard to the proposed extension to a school (details supplied) in County Offaly.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position with regard to the proposed extension to a school (details supplied) in County Offaly.

When this examination has been completed and the documentation found to be satisfactory, approval will be given to the County Offaly Vocational Education Committee to proceed with the preparation of the working drawings.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is satisfied at the rate of progress in dealing with applications under the social employment scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I am satisfied with the rate of progress under the social employment scheme. The target figure for the first year is 10,000 jobs. To date the number of jobs approved is in excess of 2,300 involving 300 projects. A further 1,100 projects with an employment potential of 3,200 persons are being processed by the National Manpower Service.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Payment of Wages Arrears.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when claims made by former employees of a firm (details supplied) in County Cork under the Insolvency Fund Act, 1983, will be adjudicated upon.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Payments under the Protection of Employees (Employers' Insolvency) Act, 1984, in respect of arrears of wages and holiday pay were made to the liquidator of the firm on 20 May, for distribution to 138 former employees. Fourteen of these employees claimed further payments for work on days off. These claims are being examined in consultation with the Department's legal advisers.

MainHeading.P: I understand that the Employment Appeals Tribunal has made an award recently in respect of 133 employees' entitlements under the Minimum Notice and Terms of Employment Act. The employees concerned should now submit their claims for payment to the liquidator of the company.

An application relating to payment arising from an Employment Appeals Tribunal award under the Unfair Dismissals Act and the Minimum Notice and Terms of Employment Act in respect of one employee will be dealt with when furthér information, which has been requested from the liquidator, is received.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when the lump sum promised to a person (details supplied) in County Cork in respect of the employment incentive scheme will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: An application by the person concerned for payment of capitalised pay related benefit under the enterprise allowance scheme has been approved and arrangements for payment as soon as possible are being made in consultation with the Department of Social Welfare.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Galway Grant Approved Projects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will give details of grants approved for projects in County Galway since the last sitting day of Dáil Éireann; and if he will give the amount of the grant in each case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I have already replied to similar questions from the Deputy on a weekly basis in the period from 24 April 1985 to 11 June 1985. Within the last two weeks nine people from the Galway area have been approved grants under the enterprise allowance scheme. Four are married and will receive £50 per week for the duration of their entitlement. The other five who are single will receive £30 per week.

MainHeading.P: Under the AnCO domestic industry grants scheme two firms in the Galway area were approved grants of £9,166 and £21,010 respectively. In addition, five firms from the Galway area were approved the following grants respectively under the AnCO technical assistance grants scheme — £80, £70, £255, £345 and £2,302.50.
